body.p:
HendersonAug 18th 1863
To His Excellency
J. F. Robinson
Sir:

At the Decr term of the , Henderson Circuit Courtwas tried under the charge of grand larceny, & the jury, failing to agree, he was bailed in the sum of $500 -- decBenj Singleton Milton Youngd becoming his surety. He failed to appear at the June term 1863, in discharge of his bond, & it was taken as forefeited.

Singleton, when indicted, was in , having enlisted in , of which state he was a citizen, & was a mere boy. His witnesses were members of his regiment. & during the court at which he was tried, were removed from this county to the Federal serviceIndiana. On the trial a majority of the jury were in favor of his acquittal.Tennessee

In Jany last, Milton Young, who became Singleton's surety from mere kindness -- died, whilst on his way to , to attend the legislature, of which he was a member. a widow & eleven children survive him, & it will be a great hardship on them, if compelled to pay off this bond.Frankfort
We think this a case that commends itself to your clemency, & respectfully & urgently entreat you to remit the forfeiture --

Yr Obt Svts.
& S B Vance AdmJohn Young Brownrs of Milton Young decd

p.note: P S No Judgment has been rendered on the bond. & the Comlths Atty has no interest in it -- Resptfully V &. B

body.p: The facts in this case are correctly set forth in this letter -- I think the case one in which the executive should interfere -- I therefore respectfully request your Excellency to grant the relief asked
